text: So the easiest way to do it is to just use constant fall, which is what we did 12 years ago when we started doing this. But again, that leaves you open to having a big exposure when a signal is just barely past zero in terms of direction. And that's not satisfying. It's hard to explain to clients. Seems to work okay. But I think we can do just a little bit better. So think about sort of the distribution of possible signals as a bell curve. It's not the normal distribution bell curve, but imagine that it's shaped like a bell curve. And you start from a signal of zero that's in the middle. And as you take steps away from zero in terms of signal, you become more confident the signal is not noise. But there's this distribution of possible signals. And as you get further from the middle, you become less confident that it can continue out into the tail because there's just less room in that tail. Right? There's the area under the curve gets smaller and smaller as your signal gets bigger and bigger. And so. Ideally, what you would do is you would model those two characteristics separately. As your signal gets bigger, you have more confidence that it's not noise. You want to invest more in it. But as your signal gets bigger, you have less confidence that could continue. And so you, you know, sort of pull away from investing in it. We model those two dynamics separately and then we aggregate them. And that's what gives us our aggregate confidence in a signal.
